name: Olloudios

attributes.attribute: local divinity (Genius Loci) worshiped in a Tree
name seems to derive from two words for “great tree” or “giant tree” (ollo-vidio)
special region was the islands off the south of France called the Antibes
honored by the tribe called the Narbonenses
depicted as having huge ears that stuck out from his head like wings
location in Britain where Olloudios was depicted as having huge ears that stuck out from his head like wings

sources: Ross, Anne. Pagan Celtic Britain: Studies in Iconography and Tradition. London: Routledge & Kegan Paul, 1967, 37, 172.
Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: The deity Olloudios (also known as Ollouidias or Olludio) was part of the Continental Celtic and British pantheon. Despite being a relatively unknown Gaulish god, he may have been a local divinity (Genius Loci) revered in a Tree. This hypothesis is supported by the fact that his name appears to derive from two words indicating a "great tree" or "giant tree" (ollo-vidio). Olloudios' worship was concentrated on the islands off the south of France known as the Antibes, where the Narbonenses tribe venerated him. Records show that Olloudios was also present in Britain, particularly in Gloucester, where he was depicted with protruding ears resembling wings.
